title: Physical pendulums - length on Mars - same period

content.question: A simple pendulum has a length of <math alttext="1.0 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> and takes a time <math alttext="T sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> to complete one oscillation on Earth. What length would a pendulum have to have on Mars, where the acceleration due to gravity is <math alttext="3.7 meters per second squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>7</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext><mo>/</mo><msup><mtext>s</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msup></math>, in order to have the same period?

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
